title: PROJECTS
text:
We investigate physiological mechanisms in fish (and other animals) from a variety of habitats to characterise their resilience and vulnerability under natural and human-associated environmental change. Open-minded and joy filled whiteboard brainstorming session is one of our favorite lab activities!












Ecological physiology of fish across body sizes and lifestages


 As fish grow and mature, they may shift habitats, encounter new environmental stressors, and reallocate energy from growth toward reproduction. Our projects explore both acute and acclimation responses in fish and other ectotherms across body size (and life-stags) as they face a range of environmental challenges. Through this work, we aim to better understand the physiological mechanisms that drive species’ vulnerability or resilience in dynamic ecosystems.








No matching items











Native and invasive crayfish in urban streams


 Freshwater salinization is an emerging concern across urban landscapes, impacting stream ecosystems and aquatic life. Our current projects compare the effects of elevated salinity (NaCl) on metabolic rates in native and widely distributed invasive crayfish species in Maryland with the aim to understand better the physiological capacities that may contribute to the success of invasive species in urbanized freshwater systems.








No matching items











Ecological toxicology. Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) in aquatic systems


 PFAS, often called “forever chemicals,” are a broad class of persistent and bioaccumulative compounds found globally in water, air, soil, sediment. Exposure to PFAS can have harmful effects on the health of both animals and humans. Our research focuses on understanding PFAS bioaccumulation across food webs in wild ecosystems, where exposure varies across time and space. In the lab, we investigate the causes and consequences of PFAS uptake in fish.








No matching items


Check in soon to learn more about the upcoming collaborative projects on anemones, turtles, and tadpoles.

title: TEACHING
text:
I strive to adopt feedback-guided flexible teaching approaches that help students take agency in their learning process and build confidence that fosters their connection to the material. Alongside of effective content delivery, community culture where all students are valued and respected by their instructor and peers is my top priority. I celebrate when students find joy in learning and stay curious!


BIOL 325: Animal Physiology



BIOL 604: Mechanisms in Animal Physiology



BIOL 206L: Biology II: Introduction to Ecology and Evolution [Lab]



BIOL 601: Current topics in a specific area of biology. The area varies each time the course is offered.

title: Fish (and other animal) ecological physiology
text:
Welcome to the Ecological Physiology Lab at Towson University! We explore how aquatic ectotherms—especially fish—respond to various natural and human-induced environmental stressors such as temperature fluctuations, salinity changes, hypoxia, altered flows, and toxicants.
We take an integrative approach, combining laboratory experiments, field studies, and quantitative techniques to examine various aspects of animal physiology, which include but are not limited to metabolic rates, cardiac performance and swimming performance. Rooted in a spirit of teamwork and cultivating a supportive environment for everyone we strive to generate insights that can inform conservation and management strategies for aquatic ecosystems.


We are always excited to exchange ideas and establish new connections– If you are interested in what we do and would like to join the lab - we would love to hear from you!


 Image (art) credit: Vinicius Goecks

title: TEAM
text:
Join us! We are always happy to hear from interested undergraduate and graduate students.





  
   

     
    
    
      
      
        
          
          
          
            
              
              
            
              
          
          
          
            
            
              Krista Kraskura 
            
               
            
              Assistant Professor
              
            

            
              I am curious about how physiological mechanisms enable fish and other animals to withstand environmental challenge. I am particularlly excited to explore how organisms' physiological performance changes across body size, life-stages, and between the 'lab' and field animals. On my free time, I love to stay active, hike, stare into the water to find animals, and try new things like pottery, and gardening!
            

            
              
            
            
            
            
            
          
      
      
    
  
    
  



No matching items




  
   

     
    
    
      

      
      
        
          
          
              
          
          
          
            
            
               Yvette Gaytan 
            
               
            
              Master's Student 
            

            
               
              'I love fish! I am especially interested in temperature tolerance, blood physiology and blood cell morphology, and how climate change affects fish's performance curves. Outside of research, I dabbles in many hobbies including weightlifting, video gaming, and playing guitar.'
              
            

            
              
            
            
            
                  

            
            
            
          
      
      
    
  
     
    
    
      

      
      
        
          
          
              
          
          
          
            
            
               Abi Millholland 
            
               
            
              Master's Student. Co-mentored with Dr. Ryan
 
            

            
               
              'I am broadly interested in the effects of environmental change on populations and their ecological roles. Specifically, I am interested in how genetic connectivity, adaptation, and phenotypic plasticity influence a species' ability to adjust to the changing environment. I enjoy hiking, fishing, herping, and being outside in any capacity! I also enjoy playing the guitar when I can.'
              
            

            
              
            
            
            
                  

            
            
            
          
      
      
    
  
     
    
    
      

      
      
        
          
          
              
          
          
          
            
            
               Faith Matthews 
            
               
            
              Undergraduate Student. Co-mentored with Dr. Salice 
            

            
               
              'I explore the ecological impacts of freshwater salinization in Maryland, specifically how salinity affects sex-specific metabolic performance in the native Common crayfish and the invasive Virile crayfish. My goals are to uncover the physiological mechanisms behind the success of invasive species and to contribute insights that inform future conservation and resource management strategies. More broadly, I am passionate about watershed ecology, conservation, and sustainability. I enjoy gardening, drawing and painting, and exploring the outdoors—activities that deepen my appreciation for the natural systems I study!'
